text: - Welcome to "Back the Basics".
In this episode, I'm gonna show you
how you can conduct data collaboration
with partners without sharing

or revealing underlying data
sets with AWS Clean Rooms.
I often work with customers
who are looking to securely combine

and analyze sensitive data
sets from different sources

without compromising privacy
and compliance standards.

As an example, let's consider
the following scenario.

There are three companies,
a popular sneaker brand,

a market research firm, and a
digital advertising platform.
They are collaborating
on an upcoming marketing campaign study.

They need to share and
collaborate on the same data set
to measure the impact

of a marketing campaign
on their brand recognition
and if it boosts sales.
To conduct this study,

the brand needs the digital
advertising platform

and the market research firm
to combine their data sets.

However, privacy and
security compliance require

that private data is not
shared with partners.
First, let's start by looking

at how private data
exchange is a challenge.
Protecting data is critical,
and data owners do not want to collaborate

with partners if they can't
protect their data sets.
Data owners want to understand

how their data set's being
used, ensure its proper use,

and avoid any potential
risk of data leakage.
As a result, they may often need to choose
not to collaborate while missing out
on important business opportunities.
Let's walk through this
with our sneaker brand study example.

For the marketing campaign,
the digital ad platform
and the market research firms need
to combine their data sets.

By doing so, they can determine
if there's enough overlap

in their customer data sets
to perform the analysis.
This is done through aggregate queries,
which help identify common data points

without exposing raw data,
such as hashed IP addresses,
email addresses, or IDs.

Partners often perform
aggregate queries like count,

first to determine whether
they have sufficient overlap
for a full study

before proceeding with
further data sharing.

Based on the results
of the aggregate count,
both the digital ad platform

and the market research firm
can join their data sets
to perform further aggregate queries,
such as the average brand favorability
and the purchase intent scores

for those who viewed ads
and those who did not.

This data gives a sneaker
brand valuable insights

into the effectiveness of
their advertising strategies
and its impact on its brand.

To do this, the firms would
need to find a platform

that makes it easier to
collaborate on data sets

and apply dataset access
controls, query controls,

query output restrictions,
and query auditing.

This process may entail
a substantial amount
of work just for the setup.

Now let's explore how you
can utilize AWS Clean Rooms.

AWS Clean Rooms is a service
that enables data owners

and partners to securely
analyze and collaborate
on collective data sets
without revealing your underlying dataset.

You can control the data
associated, how data is aggregated,

and how data is joined, and
the granularity of the results.

You can configure and
associate your AWS Glue table
while specifying privacy controls

called Analysis Rules
within your AWS Clean Room.

Once the analysis rules
are set, you can specify

where query results are
saved within your S3 bucket.

Let's review how you can set
up AWS Clean Rooms to deal
with dataset collaboration.

There are four main steps to
setting up AWS Clean Rooms.
First, one of the collaboration members

creates a collaboration
and invites other members.
Then all members create configured tables,
which contain the reference
to the dataset stored in Amazon S3
and analysis rules that determine

how the dataset can be used
within the collaboration.

Next, all collaborators
then associate their dataset
within the collaboration.

Finally, once the dataset
has been associated,

the collaboration member
with the permission
to run the analysis can then run queries.

In addition, collaborations
within AWS Clean Rooms
must occur within the same region.
Once everything is set up, the partner
with the query execution permissions

can start running queries
within AWS Clean Rooms.

The output goes directly
into a specified location

in your S3 bucket, where
it can be visualized

and used for further analysis
without anyone having access
to anyone else's raw data set.
Here's the important thing.

No raw data is moved when
associating these tables.

Rather, each participant
is giving permission
for access only for the purposes
of performing the analysis.

Dataset collaboration with
AWS Clean Rooms can be done
with multiple partners.

You can have multiple
parties in a collaboration
allowing you to collaborate

and protect data across
several partner data sets.
AWS Clean Rooms is ideal for use cases
where the dataset is structured
and the privacy of data is a main factor.
If data is unstructured

or does not have privacy
constraints, other services

such as AWS Lake Formation,
AWS Data Exchange,

or Amazon Redshift data
sharing may be better suited.
There you have it, protected

and simplified dataset
collaboration with AWS Clean Rooms.

Check out the links in
the description below
for more details.
Thanks for watching "Back to Basics".
See you next time.
